title: Table of Nations
shortSummary: Genesis 10 provides a genealogical record known as the Table of Nations, detailing the descendants of Noah's three sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—after the Flood. This chapter traces the origins of various peoples and nations, illustrating God's sovereign hand in the distribution and multiplication of humanity across the earth. It highlights the fulfillment of God's command to be fruitful and multiply, setting the stage for the unfolding biblical narrative.

keyCharacters.name: Noah
keyCharacters.description: The righteous man through whom God preserved humanity during the Flood; father of Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

keyCharacters.name: Shem
keyCharacters.description: One of Noah’s sons, ancestor of the Semitic peoples, including the line leading to Abraham.

keyCharacters.name: Ham
keyCharacters.description: Son of Noah, ancestor of various nations including Cush, Mizraim, and Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: Japheth
keyCharacters.description: Son of Noah, ancestor of many peoples who inhabited the coastlands and islands.

keyCharacters.name: Nimrod
keyCharacters.description: A mighty hunter and ruler descended from Cush, known for founding early cities such as Babel and Nineveh.

definitions.definition: A term used in the Bible to denote genealogies or family lineages, often linking historical narratives.
A phrase describing Nimrod’s prowess and leadership, indicating strength and authority before the LORD.
Refers to the distant islands and coastal regions inhabited by non-Israelite peoples, emphasizing the spread of nations.
An archaic term for language or dialect, highlighting the diversity of peoples after the Flood.

outline.heading: Introduction to Noah’s Descendants
outline.description: This section lists the sons of Japheth and their descendants, emphasizing the division of the Gentile nations by language and territory, illustrating God's sovereign distribution of peoples.

outline.heading: Descendants of Ham and the Rise of Nimrod
outline.description: Details the sons of Ham and their families, highlighting Nimrod as a mighty hunter and city-builder, and tracing the origins of various Canaanite tribes and their territories.

outline.heading: Descendants of Shem and the Line of Eber
outline.description: Focuses on Shem’s lineage, including the ancestors of the Hebrews, with special attention to Eber and his sons, marking the division of the earth during Peleg’s days.

outline.heading: Summary of the Nations’ Division
outline.description: Concludes the chapter by summarizing the families of Noah’s sons and how the nations were divided on the earth after the Flood, fulfilling God’s command to multiply and fill the earth.

application: Recognize God’s sovereign hand in the diversity of nations and peoples, encouraging respect for His divine order and plan.
Trust in God’s faithfulness to His promises, as seen in the fulfillment of the command to multiply and fill the earth after the Flood.
Embrace the unity of humanity under God despite cultural and linguistic differences, fostering a spirit of reconciliation and witness.
Learn from Nimrod’s example that earthly power and might must be understood in light of submission to God’s authority.

keyVerses.text: Now these are the generations of the sons of Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth: and unto them were sons born after the flood.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the genealogical record that explains the repopulation of the earth after the Flood.

keyVerses.text: And Cush begat Nimrod: he began to be a mighty one in the earth. He was a mighty hunter before the LORD: wherefore it is said, Even as Nimrod the mighty hunter before the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights Nimrod’s prominence as a powerful leader and hunter, setting a precedent for human leadership under God.

keyVerses.text: And unto Eber were born two sons: the name of one was Peleg; for in his days was the earth divided; and his brother's name was Joktan.
keyVerses.significance: Marks a significant event in human history—the division of the earth—likely referring to the scattering at Babel.

keyVerses.text: These are the families of the sons of Noah, after their generations, in their nations: and by these were the nations divided in the earth after the flood.
keyVerses.significance: Summarizes the chapter’s main theme of the origin and division of nations, fulfilling God’s command to fill the earth.
